(2020) use η2​K2​σ22​Ksuperscript𝜂2superscript𝐾2superscript𝜎22𝐾\frac{\eta^{2}K^{2}\sigma^{2}}{2K} with η≤8​L​K𝜂8𝐿𝐾\eta\leq 8LK (their Lemma 8), which causes the difference between their original bounds and our recovered bounds. (ii) This difference also exists in the other two cases. (iii) Their Assumption A1 is essentially equivalent to Assumption 6. For simplicity, we let B=1𝐵1B=1 in their Assumption A1 for all three cases.Even the weaker Assumption 3 is used in Koloskova et al. (2020), we do not consider it is a improvement over ours in this paper, given the discussions in Subsection 4.1.Applying Karimireddy et al. (2020)’s Lemma 1 instead of their Theorem 3 yields this bound. Notably, Woodworth et al. (2020b) assume the average of the local parameters for all iterations can be obtained, which is in fact impractical in FL. Similar assumptions are made in Khaled et al. (2020); Koloskova et al. (2020). In this paper, we omit this difference.We let P=1,M=0formulae-sequence𝑃1𝑀0P=1,M=0 in Koloskova et al. (2020)’s Assumption 3b.We let β=0𝛽0\beta=0 in Assumption 6.
references: Unless otherwise stated, our comparisons are in terms of training rounds, which is also adopted in Gao et al. (2021). This comparison (running for the same number of total training rounds R𝑅R) is fair when considering the same total computation cost for both methods. We summarize the existing convergence results of PFL in Table 1.

The upper bounds of SFL are better than PFL on heterogeneous data. As shown in Table 1 (Theorems 1 and 5), the upper bound of SFL is better than that of PFL, with an advantage of 1/M1𝑀1/M on the second and third terms (marked in red). This benefits from its sequential and shuffling-based training manner of SFL.

As shown in Table 1, the results of PFL under Assumption 7 are highlighted with a gray background and the results of SFL (under Assumption 5) are highlighted with a green background. These bounds closely resembles each other, with three error terms (the first three terms containing σ𝜎\sigma, ζ𝜁\zeta) and one optimization term (the last one). To emphasize the role of heterogeneity, we let σ=0,μ=L=D=1formulae-sequence𝜎0𝜇𝐿𝐷1\sigma=0,\mu=L=D=1 as done in Woodworth et al. (2020b).

S6.T2.caption: Table 2: Settings of simulated experiments. Each group has two local objectives (M=2𝑀2M=2). Strictly speaking, the functions in Groups 4, 5, 9, 10 are not quadratic functions.
references: Results of simulated experiments. As shown in Table 2, we use ten groups of objective functions with various degrees of heterogeneity. In fact, we construct the lower bounds in Theorem 3 with similar functions. As suggested by our theory, we set the learning rate of SFL be half of that of PFL. The experimental results of Table 2 are shown in Figure 1.

S6.T3.caption: Table 3: Training and Test accuracy results with various degrees of heterogeneity in cross-device settings. We run PFL and SFL for 2000/5000/5000 training rounds on Fashion-MNIST/CIFAR-10/CINIC-10. Results are computed across three random seeds and the last 100 training rounds.

Dataset Method C=1𝐶1C=1 C=2𝐶2C=2 C=5𝐶5C=5
Train Test Train Test Train Test
Fashion-MNIST PFL 86.71±plus-or-minus\pm1.87 85.77±plus-or-minus\pm1.96 89.73±plus-or-minus\pm1.23 88.55±plus-or-minus\pm1.19 92.27±plus-or-minus\pm0.57 90.70±plus-or-minus\pm0.50
SFL 88.86±plus-or-minus\pm1.60 87.60±plus-or-minus\pm1.56 91.33±plus-or-minus\pm1.49 89.66±plus-or-minus\pm1.41 92.83±plus-or-minus\pm0.69 90.92±plus-or-minus\pm0.64
CIFAR-10 PFL 76.48±plus-or-minus\pm2.03 73.84±plus-or-minus\pm1.90 85.92±plus-or-minus\pm1.77 78.99±plus-or-minus\pm1.43 94.55±plus-or-minus\pm0.36 83.47±plus-or-minus\pm0.48
SFL 89.60±plus-or-minus\pm2.29 81.05±plus-or-minus\pm1.78 94.01±plus-or-minus\pm0.97 83.34±plus-or-minus\pm0.68 96.72±plus-or-minus\pm0.50 84.73±plus-or-minus\pm0.44
CINIC-10 PFL 53.36±plus-or-minus\pm3.80 52.27±plus-or-minus\pm3.61 65.38±plus-or-minus\pm2.01 61.96±plus-or-minus\pm1.81 74.97±plus-or-minus\pm0.95 68.45±plus-or-minus\pm0.81
SFL 65.40±plus-or-minus\pm3.57 61.52±plus-or-minus\pm3.14 73.58±plus-or-minus\pm2.32 67.31±plus-or-minus\pm1.87 79.58±plus-or-minus\pm1.42 70.82±plus-or-minus\pm1.05
references: SFL outperforms PFL on heterogeneous data. The accuracy results on training data and test data for various tasks are collected in Table 3. In particular, the test accuracy curves on CIFAR-10 are shown in Figure 2. It can be observed (i) that when the level of heterogeneity is high (for example, C=1,2𝐶12C=1,2) the performance of SFL is much better than that of PFL, and (ii) that when the level of heterogeneity is relatively low, the performances of both are close to each other. This is consistent with analyses in Subsections 5.1 and 5.2. Besides, on the more complex data set CINIC-10, the advantage of SFL seems to be even greater, which may be due to higher heterogeneity.

references: When 1≤m≤M1𝑚𝑀1\leq m\leq M and 0<k≤K−10𝑘𝐾10<k\leq K-1, similarly, we can first prove that 𝒜m,ksubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘{\mathcal{A}}_{m,k} is symmetric and then compute ℙ​(𝒜m,k=0)ℙsubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘0\mathbb{P}({\mathcal{A}}_{m,k}=0). As shown in Table 7, we conclude all cases into four categories 𝒜m,k=−p−aksubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘𝑝subscript𝑎𝑘{\mathcal{A}}_{m,k}=-p-a_{k}, 𝒜m,k=−p+aksubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘𝑝subscript𝑎𝑘{\mathcal{A}}_{m,k}=-p+a_{k}, 𝒜m,k=p−aksubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘𝑝subscript𝑎𝑘{\mathcal{A}}_{m,k}=p-a_{k} and 𝒜m,k=p+aksubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘𝑝subscript𝑎𝑘{\mathcal{A}}_{m,k}=p+a_{k}. We can get that the probability distribution of 𝒜m,ksubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘{\mathcal{A}}_{m,k} is symmetric. Furthermore, since 0<ak<10subscript𝑎𝑘10<a_{k}<1, we can get that ℙ​(𝒜m,k=0)=0ℙsubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘00\mathbb{P}({\mathcal{A}}_{m,k}=0)=0, and thus ℙ​(𝒜m,k>0)=ℙ​(𝒜m,k<0)=12ℙsubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘0ℙsubscript𝒜𝑚𝑘012\mathbb{P}({\mathcal{A}}_{m,k}>0)=\mathbb{P}({\mathcal{A}}_{m,k}<0)=\frac{1}{2}.
